awd_titl_txt: Conference Support: Participation of US Students and Junior Faculty to the 6th World Congress on Micro and Nano Manufacturing (WCMNM 2023); Evanston, Illinois; 18-21 September 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
The grant provides support for 30 students and junior faculty from US institutions to participate in the 6th World Congress on Micro and Nano Manufacturing (WCMNM 2023) in Evanston, Illinois, 18-21 September 2023. WCMNM is a premier global conference on micro-nano manufacturing and draws attendance of 150-300 people each year from North America, Europe, and Asia. WCMNM serves as an important platform for exchanging research ideas and fostering collaborations for both academia and industry. Over 80 technical presentations and posters are expected to be presented at the conference. A wide range of topics, including mechanics and dynamics of process behaviors at the micro and nanoscale; miniaturization of machines and equipment; micro-factory paradigms; microscale metrology; materials handling; multi-scale modeling and simulation; design for micro-scale manufacturing; micro and nano additive manufacturing technologies, etc., will be covered.

Participating students receiving travel funds from this grant will learn from the unique intellectual environment by attending technical presentations by leading international experts in micro/nano manufacturing, and by interacting with peer researchers from around the world. They will have opportunities to network with researchers and engineers from around the world as well as graduate students working in the manufacturing field. This experience will be valuable for graduate students to gain new insights about future career paths and emerging research frontiers. In addition, becoming involved with professional societies will motivate their intellectual curiosity through developing a network of professional contacts. By involving keynote and invited speakers from the three co-organizing societies, this conference will provide graduate students and junior faculty a platform to facilitate international collaboration and research exchange. Specific outreach efforts will be devoted to advertising the conference and the student travel award program to underrepresented minorities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The project provided financial support for students and postdocs studying in U.S. institutions to participate in the 6th World Congress on Micro and Nano Manufacturing (WCMNM 2023) that was held in Evanston IL, 18-21, September 2023.  WCMNM is a premier global conference on micro-nano manufacturing which is jointly organized by three institutions; International Institution for Micro Manufacturing (I2M2) based in USA, 4M Association (based in Europe), and the International Forum for Micro Manufacturing (IFMM) based in Asia. WCMNM serves as a platform for exchange of ideas in the field of micro-nano manufacturing and engineering. The conference hosted participants and perspectives from 16 different countries spanning North and South America, Asia, and Europe, as well as 11 different States in the U.S.

This congress featured 21 sessions for oral presentations. A total of 75 paper presentations, 4 invited talks (from mid-career researchers), and 5 plenary talks (from prominent researchers in the fields and NSF program manager) were delivered at the congress. The papers presented in this congress addressed theoretical and applied research featuring numerous topics including micro additive manufacturing, micro ECM and EDM, processing sensing and data analytics, micro/nano composites, micro forming, micro machining, micro mechanics and modeling, micro-structured surfaces, machine and process designs, surface treatment, and tooling.

There was a total of 120 registered participants of the conference. The grant was used to provide partial financial supports of 31 students and postdocs including registration fees, hotel rooms, and travel. Each supported participant attended conference sessions where papers relevant to his/her field of research were presented. The student participants were also required to attend keynote speeches given by eminent scholars in the field, and they were encouraged to discuss with other participants during tea break, welcome reception, banquet dinner, and tours as part of networking.

This grant has provided the student participants greater opportunities for networking, fostered future collaborations and exchange of ideas with other researchers in the discipline which should enhance likelihood of future innovation. This experience is very valuable to young engineers in developing their careers in the manufacturing field.

 


Last Modified: 04/07/2024
Modified by: Ping Guo
